The  Fisheries  and  Marine  Environmental  Service  (FMES)  in  the
Division  of  Agricultural  Affairs  has  embarked  on  an  ambitious
strategic development plan for East Timor’s fisheries. One of the
plan’s  cornerstones  is  a  precautionary  approach  for  developing
inshore fisheries by targeting the much larger and robust pelagic
resources  offshore.  Rehabilitation  of  the  fishing  harbor  basin  will
provide the future government of East Timor with one of the tools
necessary  to  implement  a  responsible  fisheries  management
regime.  An  operational  fishing  harbor  will  provide  basic  support
services  and  thus  act  as  a  strong  incentive  for  the  return  and
operation of the fishing vessels currently located at Atauro Island,
and act as a catalyst to shift fishing effort to the offshore fisheries.

East  Timor’s  coastline  is  only  about  650  kilometers  (km)  long,
most  with  little  or  no  coral  reef.  No  areas  of  barrier  reef  or  sea
mounts are within reach of the small-scale sector. The island has
very little continental shelf; depths of 200 meters (m) are reached
within 2-8 km of the shore, and depths of 2,000 to 3,000 m within
20  km.  All  coastal  demersal  resources  are  limited  to  a  narrow
stretch of steep to fairly steeply sloping seabed.

Fisheries restoration and most future development plans are likely
to  be  based  on  East  Timor’s  pelagic  resources,  including  small
pelagic species such as Indian mackerel, scad, sardines, and the
small  tuna.  In  due  course,  skills  will  be  developed  to  exploit
resources of the high-value larger tuna species.

Coral  reef  fisheries  will  be  liable  to  overfishing  if  placed  under
concerted  commercial  fishing  pressure.  Probably  only  local
indigenous fishers should be allowed to fish coral reefs.

BACKGROUND

3.
Accurate  historical  data  is  not  available  for  inshore  fisheries  in  East  Timor  in  terms  of
current fishing effort (boats, gear, fishers), or the extent of coastal living marine resources. An
Indonesian statistical report on the number of fishing gear units in East Timor published in 19974
identified 630 fishing vessels with outboard engines, with 349 in Dili alone, and 1,387 canoes.
Also,  in  1997,  9,066  fishers  caught  a  total  of  2,423  tons  of  marine  fish.  Available  data  and
informed  anecdotal  information  indicate  that  the  Indonesian  withdrawal  resulted  in  substantial
losses of fishing gear and vessels. Several surveys have tried to calculate the actual losses, but
too many error factors were encountered to give an accurate assessment.

If  not  controlled,  economic  interests  relating  to  the  coastal  zone  will  constitute

Destruction  of  near-shore  resources  typically  impacts  the  poor  segments  of  the
population.  Small-scale  artisanal  fishers  are  most  dependent  on  fish  resources
close to the shore.

The East Timorese coastal zone is characterized by a narrow or nonexistent continental
5.
shelf,  a  limited  amount  of  fringing  coral  reef,  and  a  number  of  fragile  ecosystem  pockets
(mangroves,  sea  grasses,  etc.).  These  areas  are  likely  to  support  limited  coastal  marine
resources.  As  the  economy  recovers,  the  demand  (and  markets)  for  fisheries  resources  will
increase and early attention will be required to ensure sustainability of target species.

6.
East Timor is faced with the dual task of trying to restore its fishery and at the same time
trying  to  promote  a  sustainable  fishery,  avoiding  the  numerous  failed  tropical  fisheries
interventions  that  have  been  the  hallmark  of  the  sector.  Judging  from  other  similar  areas  of
marine  waters,  a  conservative  estimate  points  to  a  minimum  sustainable  harvest  per  year  of
around  15,000  tons.  The  minimum  recommended  fish  consumption  per  capita  per  year
according to the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations of 13 kilograms
(kg)  would  require  production  of  9,400  tons  just  to  satisfy  the  recommended  need  of  East
Timor’s population.

7.
The  fisheries  sector,  nevertheless,  offers  considerable  potential  not  only  to  sustain  the
important  subsistence  subsector,  but  also  for  job  creation  in  commercial  activities  and  related
downstream activities, e.g., marketing, processing, provisioning, servicing, etc. Once East Timor
has  an  accepted  exclusive  economic  fishing  zone,  the  offshore  resources  will  be  fully
accessible.  During  Indonesian  rule  of  the  country  these  resources  were  off-limits  to  the  East
Timorese and were harvested by Indonesian fishers primarily from Sulawesi.

8.
The Indonesian withdrawal caused a void of personnel in fisheries administration, which
is  only  slowly  being  filled,  albeit  with  a  lot  less  people.  This  is  a  deliberate  strategy  by  the
Fisheries  and  Marine  Environment  Service  (FMES),  which  will  focus  on  management,
legislation, policies, and enforcement issues, and leave the practical and commercial aspects to
the  private  sector.  A  major  task,  however,  will  be  to  cut  through  the  leftover  inefficient
bureaucracy;  East  Timor  will  need  foreign  assistance  in  the  foreseeable  future  to  achieve  its
objectives as stipulated in its  strategic plan for fisheries.6

The  development  and  management  of  a  sustainable  fisheries  sector  will  directly

Governance

19.
The  new  nation  of  East  Timor  will  face  many  governance  challenges.    Democratic
processes  are  in  the  process  of  being  introduced.  Self-government  is  a  relatively  new  and
emerging  concept.  The  challenge  will  be  to  rebuild  trust  as  a  first  step  to  participating  in
government,  especially  at  the  local  level.  Good  governance  requires  a  skills  base  to  provide
basic  government  services.  Basic  education,  preventive  health  care,  family  planning,  and
improved  agricultural  production  are  the  priority  areas  for  investment  and  capacity  building.
Important infrastructure is needed to facilitate the delivery of education and health services, and
to  stimulate  commercial  activity,  especially  in  the  agriculture  sector.  The  reconstruction  and
staffing  of  schools  and  health  clinics  are  also  priorities.  The  speedy  reconstruction  of  land
transport infrastructure is critical to economic development.

3. 

Social Development

Education  indicators  are  generally  poor.  Literacy  rates  were  last  officially  recorded  in
20.
1986 when literacy was 51 percent on a national basis, and 64 percent among adults. Evidence
suggests that education enrollment has a distinct gender bias. For example, in 1998, 52 percent
of  females  over  10  years  of  age  had  never  been  to  school.  Postprimary  education  is  still
disrupted, and literacy among the rural poor is less than 50 percent.

21.
The upheaval in 1999 had a serious impact on health services. Most facilities have been
damaged, and 130 of 160 physicians have departed. Existing services in rural communities are
extremely  limited.  However,  emergency  services  are  in  place  provided  by  nongovernment
organizations  (NGOs)  and  donors.  Prior  to  1999,  life  expectancy  was  around  55  to  58  years.
Infant mortality was moderately high at 85 deaths per 1,000 births, and medical staff attended
only 37 percent of all births. The under-five mortality rate was moderately high at 124 deaths per
1,000 births, and immunization rates varied from 60-90 percent. Only 25 percent of villages had
a health clinic, and the average distance to a hospital was 75 kilometers (km).

E. 

Lessons Learned

22.
Past  fisheries  projects  have  often  been  synonymous  with  failures.  The  objectives
focused  on  (i)  increasing  catches  by  increasing  the  number  and  size  of  vessels,  and  (ii)
increasing quality by providing ice factories and cold storage. The difficulties in assessing fish
stocks  and  the  unregulated  nature  of  most  fisheries  (open  access)  inevitably  lead  to
considerable  overcapitalization  of  the  industry  and  subsequent  declining  catch  rates.  Another
important lesson learned is the incompatible mix of direct government involvement in the sector
together with the commercial operators. Sound business practices were compromised by social
obligations to government employment, and government officials employed in the fisheries were
not  accountable  for  the  quality  of  day-to-day  services,  such  as  facilitating  efficient  fish  landing
operations;  and  providing  market  mechanisms,  and  repair  and  maintenance  facilities  when
needed.

23.
For  East  Timor,  this  is  the  most  opportune  time  to  implement  responsible  fisheries
management  with  emphasis  on  sustainability  of  the  sector.  The  strategic  plan  for  fisheries
(footnote  6)  has  clearly  taken  the  lessons  learned  into  consideration.  This  alone  is,  of  course,
not a guarantee against failures in the future, but the prioritization of the precautionary approach
to the development of the fisheries sector further underpins the justification for this Project.

F. 

Policy Dialogue

24.
Given  that  East  Timor  is  still  under  transitional  administration  by  the  United  Nations,
formalized  policy  dialogue  with  a  national  government  has  not  been  possible.  However,
continuous  consultations  with  FMES  have  been  undertaken  and  a  progressive  approach  to
fisheries development agreed upon, based on the strategic plan. Furthermore, the World Bank
and  ADB  have  collaborated  closely  on  the  selection  of  consultants  for  fisheries  projects  to
ensure  that  lessons  learned  from  other  fisheries  projects  are  given  a  high  priority.  The
formulation of the strategic plan for fisheries received substantial input from one of the fielded
consultants  under  World  Bank  funding.  The  strategic  plan  conforms  to  both  World  Bank  and
ADB precautionary policies for the capture fisheries sector.

IV. 

THE PROJECT

A. 

Rationale

25.
The  absence  of  a  functional  fishing  harbor  in  East  Timor  makes  it  very  difficult—if  not
impossible—for  FMES  to  implement  responsible  fisheries  management.  The  limited  inshore
resource needs a very controlled fishing effort to ensure its sustainability. However, the offshore
resources  are  robust  and  fast  growing,  and  offer  an  opportunity  for  limited  development.  The
vessels for such an offshore-based fishery need a dedicated fisheries harbor as a base, as the
vessels are too large to beach. Hera Port was built under a previous ADB loan10 and was only
completed in 1993. However, problems in visiting East Timor at that time meant that maintaining
close  monitoring  of  the  project  was  difficult.  Construction  inadequacies  have  caused  the
structures to rapidly deteriorate.

26.
The fisheries harbor rehabilitation at Hera will provide improved mooring and unloading
facilities,  and  act  as  a  center  for  the  receipt,  processing,  and  distribution  of  fish  for  Dili  and
beyond. Facilities are also available to supply ice, provide training, repair and maintenance for
marine engines and other fishing equipment, and boat building and/or repair. Once the harbor is
rehabilitated, Atauro fishers11 will likely be the first to relocate their fishing vessels to Hera. The
development  of  a  pelagic  fishing  fleet  will,  however,  take  several  years  as  the  level  of
investment and training will require time. In the near to medium term, the navy will place its two
patrol vessels, primarily for fisheries surveillance but also for customs duties, along the pier to
the  east  just  outside  the  harbor  basin.  These  activities  are  very  positive  for  the  overall
development  of  Hera  Port  as  they  will  naturally  attract  more  activities  and  scope  for  private
sector  enterprises.  At  this  stage,  no  significant  conservation  concerns  exist.  The  sustainability
(more  in  terms  of  local  depletions  than  biodiversity)  of  intensive  fishing  on  small  pelagics  will
need to be considered in the longer term.

B. 

Objectives and Scope

27.
The  Project’s  overall  objective  is  to  contribute  to  sustained  food  security  of  marine
protein  for  the  East  Timorese.  The  goal  is  to  achieve  responsible  fisheries  management  by
promoting the offshore pelagic fisheries and thus ease pressure on inshore fisheries. This will
be  achieved  by  rehabilitating  the  necessary  harbor  infrastructure  facilities  at  Hera  Port  for  the
larger offshore fishing vessels. The project framework is in Appendix 1.

28.
The Project is relatively modest in scope comprising the rehabilitation and strengthening
of three individual breakwaters totaling approximately 140 m in length, and rehabilitation of the
wharf faces of the harbor basin totaling approximately 400 m. The work will include replenishing
washed-away  core  material  from  the  breakwaters  and  enforcing  the  seaward  sides  with  stone
armor.  This  will  achieve  the  required  height  of  the  breakwaters  to  protect  the  harbor  basin
against  wave  action  at  all  tides.  Precast  concrete  slabs  anchored  in  profiled  steel  piles  will
enforce the wharf faces inside the harbor basin. This will create a secured mooring site for easy
on-  and  offloading  of  all  vessels.  The  working  apron  alongside  the  wharves  will  also  be
upgraded  and/or  rehabilitated.  The  Project  will  emphasize  as  much  use  of  local  labor,  local
purchase  of  materials,  and  lease  and  hire  of  equipment  from  East  Timorese  as  possible.

Technical Justification

29.
The  Project  has  devised  the  most  appropriate  solutions  to  ensure  (i)  maximum  local

them  on  the  breakwaters  can  all  be  sourced  locally.  The  face-wall  concrete  slabs  will  all  be
precast  using  local  labor  under  appropriate  supervision  by  international  and  domestic  civil
engineers.  The  use  of  precast  concrete  slabs  is  a  rather  sophisticated  method,  but  ensures
minimum  maintenance.  With  appropriate  supervision  and  correct  material  use,  available  East
Timor labor force should be able to carry out the work.

V. 

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A. 

Financial and Economic Analyses

1. 

Financial Analysis

49.
Prior  to  the  conflict,  Hera  Port  provided  support  and  services  to  a  reasonable-sized
fishing fleet targeting the pelagic fishery. Since then the port has lapsed into a state of decline;
no administration is present and the fishing fleet, or what is left of it, does not or cannot use the
port.

50.
The  Project  will  directly  support  the  sector’s  strategic  plan  and  act  as  a  catalyst  in
providing the fishing industry with much-needed confidence and facilities in harbor protection by
rehabilitating breakwaters, providing access to ice production, improving loading and unloading
facilities  at  the  wharves,  providing  repair  and  maintenance  facilities  when  the  slipway  is
rehabilitated, and improving access to trading and storage facilities.

51.
A full range of port activities is envisaged for the new operation, providing the harbor can
be rehabilitated to an operational standard. For example, tenders are now being received for the

 11

leasing  of  a  rehabilitated  ice  plant.  In  addition,  revenue  can  be  generated  from  10  different
sources:  landed  fish  fees,  berthage  and  mooring  fees,  cold  storage  facilities,  water  and  fuel
sales, lease rental of shops and workshops, accommodation, and export packaging facilities. All
these  services  will  not  be  available  immediately,  but  will  be  phased  in  over  time.  When  full
operation is achieved, the expected yearly revenue generated will be approximately $0.1 million.

52.
The  future  East  Timorese  Government  could  operate  ports,  airports,  and  harbors  as
state assets, statutory authorities, or purely commercial enterprises. For the sake of a realistic
calculation, the Project envisages a port authority with a staffing of four. The annual cost of such
an administration, in conjunction with support costs, is projected to be about $0.02 million. By
the  end  of  2002,  the  operation  of  the  port  should  achieve  a  surplus  over  operating  costs.
However,  the  planned  mooring  of  the  two  navy  patrol  vessels  at  the  pier  in  Hera  Port  would
logically point to some kind of state authority for Hera Port in the near to medium future. Their
presence are also likely to secure adequate operation and maintenance costs for the port.

a. 

Least-Cost Analysis

A  least-cost  analysis  was  carried  out  for  the  two  project  components:  the  breakwater

53.
reconstruction and the vertical wharf-face reconstruction.

In  the  case  of  the  breakwater  reconstruction,  the  three  options  are  not  different
54.
engineering  options,  but  rather  different  methods  for  applying  the  same  engineering  solution.
The  engineering  solution  is  simple,  cost  effective,  and  within  budget.  The  existing  breakwater
system with materials in place requires rehabilitation of the core and a new armor system on the
seaward sides. The source of this armor is either from a quarry or available rocks, although one
option is to make concrete tetrapods.

55.
The options were tested at a discounted rate of 8 percent and 13 percent; on all tests the
least-cost  option  requires  the  involvement  of  a  contractor  with  a  very  low  profit  margin  to
administer and manage the Project with direct purchasing from a local quarry. The equalization
discount  rate  was  not  calculated  as  the  least-cost  option  prevailed  at  the  two  testing  discount
rates  of  8  percent  and  13  percent,  with  the  13  percent  being  above  the  threshold  required  by
ADB.

56.
For reconstruction of the vertical wharf face two options considered, applying the same
methodology as for the breakwaters. The option utilizing a contractor (e.g., an NGO) and local
labor prevailed.

From a financial point of the view, with the initial investment being a grant, the operation
59.

2. 

Economic Analysis

60.
East Timor is primarily an agricultural economy, with 90 percent of the population living
in  rural  areas  and  75  percent  of  the  labor  force  engaged  in  agriculture,  primarily  subsistence
agriculture.  The  economic  framework  has  changed  dramatically,  as  East  Timor  can  no  longer
rely on transfers from the Indonesian Government. External financing now plays a major role in
the  economy,  but  this  will  be  relatively  short  term,  thus  sustainable  projects  will  form  the
backbone of future development potential.

61.
The rehabilitation of the fishing harbor at Hera offers the country a variety of economic
benefits.  Care  has  been  taken  to  ensure  that  the  claimed  benefits  equate  only  to  the
incremental effect of the harbor rehabilitation and that these benefits only bring the capacity of
the  fisheries  operations  back  to  preconflict  levels,  thus  ensuring  no  inflated  claims  for
exaggerated increases in the fisheries sector.

According  to  FMES  the  fish  catches  are  expected  to  be  easily  sustainable  at  15,000-
62.
20,000 tons per annum within the exclusive economic zone (yet to be negotiated), which would
provide the East Timorese with an annual per capita consumption level of 22 kg of fish protein.
However, achieving these levels will require substantial and sustainable development within the
sector, and will need more than the rehabilitation of Hera Port.

63.
FAO has recommended an annual level of 13 kg of fish protein per capita, as a balanced
intake. East Timor is presently producing a catch of approximately 950 tons per annum, which
gives a per capita consumption of 1.22 kg representing only 9 percent of the recommended fish
protein  intake.  Even  if  fishing  levels  are  brought  back  up  to  preconflict  levels  of  2,800  tons
(footnote  6),  this  will  only  result  in  a  per  capita  return  of  3.5  kg,  or  26  percent  of  the
recommended fish protein levels.

64.
These figures do not include the current subsistence fishing, and this will be ignored for
the economic analysis of the rehabilitation.13 The present catch is being achieved by small boats
or  bigger  canoes,  and  is  being  brought  to  shore  by  just  landing  on  the  beach.  The  size  boats
using  the  rehabilitated  harbor  at  Hera  are  expected  to  be  similar  to  those  before  the  conflict,
11 m craft, Japanese style, with a capacity of 5 gross tons.

65.
The economic analysis is based on a comparison of with- and without-project scenarios.
The  cost  and  benefit  streams  were  estimated  for  30  years  including  only  8  months  of  project
implementation. Given that UNTAET has adopted the dollar as the official currency for the time
being  in  East  Timor,  a  shadow  foreign  exchange  rate,  or  standard  conversion  factor  has  not
been  assumed  for  the  analysis.  The  main  benefits  identified  are:  fish-handling  methodologies,
fish-catch recovery, fishing fleet protection, and socioeconomic impacts.

66.

The  size  of  the  present  catch  is  950  tons  per  annum.  This  is  far  below  the  preconflict

68.

a  fleet  of  24.  With  the  harbor  offering  safe  anchorage  and  access  to  ice,  and  repair  and

B. 

Environment

76.
The  reestablishment  of  a  functional  fishing  harbor  will  enable  FMES  to  implement  its
stated  objectives  (footnote  6),  which  give  high  priority  to  protection  of  inshore  resources  in

promote  an  offshore  fishery,  which  will  directly  contribute  to  reducing  fishing  pressure  on
inshore  resources.  Another  FMES  objective  is  that  communities,  to  a  large  extent,  will  be
responsible  for  managing  the  coastal  and  inshore  resources;  but  any  management  regime
needs  to  be  underpinned  by  proper  legislation.  Such  legislation  will  be  advanced  with  the
diversification into the offshore fishery.

C. 

Social Dimensions

77.
The overall Project objective is to contribute to sustained food security. From all the data
available,  fish  protein  is  in  short  supply;  the  preconflict  level  of  fish  catches  probably  only
covered  a  maximum  of  50  percent  of  the  FAO  recommended  yearly  per  capita  consumption.
The influx of foreigners to East Timor for peacekeeping and the transitional administration has
created a dramatic increase in the prices of fish. With the mandate for the peacekeepers to run
until  2006  and  a  rather  large  contingency  of  aid  workers  who  will  continue  development
projects, the price of fish is likely to remain high in the near to medium term. However, another
and  equally  important  consideration  must  be  taken  into  account  when  analyzing  the  present
fish  supply.  Most  foreigners  prefer  reef  fish;  given  East  Timor’s  very  limited  reef  area  a  real
possibility  of  overfishing  exists.  This  would  be  to  the  long-term  detriment  of  the  traditional
subsistence fishers and the ecology.

78.
The Project will provide a functional base for larger pelagic fishing boats, which in turn,
will not only fish away from the vulnerable inshore and reef areas, but also target fish species
that are abundant, fast-growing, and generally much cheaper. The impact of increased supply
of cheaper fish will have an immediate and positive impact on the poorer people of the society
in form of better nutrition.

 15

79.
Such  a  shift  in  fisheries  management  could  also  lead  to  increased  employment  for
women  in  the  future.  Smaller  pelagic  fish  species  are  normally  most  suitable  for  drying  and
salting, activities that traditionally are dominated by women. Another advantage in promoting a
fishery  of  smaller  pelagics  is  the  fairer  distribution  of  affordable  protein  to  all  members  of  a
family,  as  everyone  will  get  an  equal  share,  and  because  smaller  fish  tend  to  be  consumed
whole, the nutritional value is much greater than when eating larger fish.

D. 

Impact on Poverty

The analysis to assess the poverty impact of this Project reflects the ADB Guidelines for
80.

Economic Analysis of Projects.

81.
According  to  the  ADB  discussion  paper  of  March  2001  on  the  poverty  assessment  in
East  Timor  (footnote  9),  75  percent  of  the  population  is  living  below  the  poverty  line.  Certain
disclaimers  to  the  results  of  that  assessment  are  noted.  However,  the  present  price  of  fish  at
approximately  $5.3  per  kg  undoubtedly  means  that  the  majority  of  the  East  Timorese  cannot
include  fish  in  their  diet.  In  the  absence  of  any  other  reliable  data,  the  FAO  guideline  for  the
minimum yearly food consumption of fish per capita is assumed to be applicable to the poverty
line.

82.
To  examine  the  poverty  impact,  the  existing  situation  was  considered  along  with  the
relationship between production and the coverage of the kg per capita daily intake at the poverty
line, based on the FAO guideline of 13 kg per capita per year for fish protein (or 0.036 kg per
capita  per  day).  With  a  yearly  production  forecast  for  2001  of  950  tons  and  a  population  of
780,000,  the  intake  of  fish  is  only  0.003  kg  per  capita  per  day.  This  equals  a  consumption
coverage at the poverty line of 8 percent.

83.
Secondly,  the  ability  of  future  production  to  meet  demand  at  the  absolute  poverty  line
without project intervention was examined. The yearly production forecast for 2015 is 3,600 tons
and the population forecast for that year is 1,019,103. This corresponds to 0.010 kg per capita
per  day,  which  equals  consumption  coverage  at  the  poverty  line  of  28  percent.  This  clearly
shows  that  without  intervention  the  fisheries  sector  cannot  achieve  the  production  levels
required.

Finally, in this analysis, the effects of this project intervention are shown to 2015. Yearly
84.
production forecast is set at 7,500 tons with population at 1,019,103. This corresponds to 0.020
kg of fish per capita per day, which equals 56 percent consumption coverage.

85.

86.

E. 

Risks

88.
One  of  the  goals  of  FMES  is  to  create  a  much  smaller  fisheries  administration  than
under  Indonesian  rule,  namely  from  approximately  120  persons  to  around  20.  The  philosophy
behind the reduction is the realization that the private sector should lead the development, with
government  providing  an  enabling  business  environment  with  the  underpinning  legislation  and
regulations. FMES’s strategy further envisages that local communities will manage the inshore
resources with a district fisheries officer as the FMES liaison.

89.
Even  with  unfavorable  changes  in  benefits  and  costs,  the  economic  returns  to  the
Project are robust. The major risk to the Project not realizing its full potential is the nonadoption
of  effective  legislation  and  an  inappropriate  institutional  framework  for  implementing  the
fisheries strategic plan. UNTAET is working to rebuild East Timor’s economy, but in reality it is
not  the  constitutionally  elected  government  and  therefore  actions  and  programs  may  well  be
subject  to  future  challenge  and  repudiation  by  an  elected  government.  However,  the  fisheries
strategic plan is based on traditional habits formed by fishers using Hera Port. Therefore, even
in the absence of appropriate legislative and institutional arrangements, Hera Port rehabilitation
will likely be a natural catalyst for the recovery of the industry, beginning with the return of the
fishers  from  Atauro  Island.  However,  one  risk  factor  is  that  local  fishers  cannot  acquire  larger
fishing  vessels.  UNTAET  has,  in  conjunction  with  FMES,  commenced  a  boat-building  project
with appropriate training facilities and programs. This project is expected to be expanded once
the harbor is again operational. The incentive to engage in the offshore fishing is the very high
current demand for fish.

90.
The pro-poor component of the Project relies on a sufficient fish catch to drive down the
current  price.  However,  among  the  foreigners  working  in  East  Timor  seafood  is  extremely

 17

popular and commands very high prices. The preferred species are the larger bottom fish and
reef fish. If the number of foreigners in East Timor remains high in the short to medium term and
the demand for seafood continues to be high, then FMES’s strategy to diversify to the offshore
fishery  may  be  stalled.  Fishers  will  naturally  continue  to  satisfy  a  demand  that  gives  high
economic returns, rather than invest in larger vessels and the associated bigger business risks.

91.
A review of other infrastructure and construction projects in and around Dili has revealed
a  substandard  implementation  quality.  Concrete  only  laid  six  months  ago  shows  signs  of
crumbling  and  is  of  suspect  strength,  breakwater  constructions  have  been  constructed  with
“armor” that is no bigger than “core” materials. Unsupervised mixing and lack of local standards
of  aggregate  and  sand  result  in  substandard  concrete,  according  to  local  and  foreign
contractors.  To  alleviate  this  problem,  procurement  packages  will  be  formulated  in  small
discrete lots with high specifications. This will prevent small “errors” in quality going unnoticed.
For example, the supply of “armor” from one source will be a different package to the supply of
“core” from another source.

Another risk is that the strategic plan adopted may be derailed under a new government,
92.
which  will  be  under  pressure  to  provide  jobs  and  economic  growth.  Precautionary  fisheries
management  is  a  long-term  investment  for  a  country  to  achieve  a  sustainable  fishery  and
ensure food security. However, short-term obligations in a country where the expectations of the
population  are  very  high  and  the  pressure  on  government  to  deliver  is  correspondingly  high,
may be factors that will sacrifice good long-term intentions for short-term obligations.

The least-cost analysis is carried out in economic (border) prices, and used to determine
which  development  option  is  preferred  economically  where  a  number  of  viable  technical
alternatives exist. The principal economic decision criteria employed is the net present value of
the sum of the discounted net cash-flow stream of the Project. It is the cumulative present worth
of  the  incremental  national  income  generated  by  the  investment.  For  the  Project  to  be
economically feasible, the net present value must be positive for a predetermined discount rate,
which reflects the opportunity cost of capital in East Timor.

21.
This requires the estimation of cost streams over the entire economic life of the Project
for each of the feasible components. For the project options that deliver the same benefits, the
equalizing discount rate between each is estimated and compared. The equalizing discount rate
(or the crossover discount rate) is the discount rate at which the preference changes. It is also
the rate at which the present values of the cost streams are equal.

22.
The  EIRR  is  the  discount  rate  that  when  applied  to  the  stream  of  incremental  benefits
and costs as reflected in the net cash flow of the project produces a zero net present value. It is
the  maximum  (real,  noninflationary)  annual  rate  of  interest  that  the  project  could  pay  for  the
resources used if the project is to recover all of its costs and still break even. For the project to
be  economically  feasible,  the  EIRR  must  be  equal  to  or  greater  than  the  opportunity  cost  of
capital in East Timor.

3. 

Fleet Protection and O&M

71.
The fishing fleet is in a bad state of repair. Only 4 or 5 boats are operational out of a fleet
of  24.  The  port  will  offer  safe  anchorage  and  access  to  repair  and  maintenance  facilities;  the
fleet is expected to rejuvenate at a rate of 5 boats per annum. In practice this may be quicker,
but this is the assumption used in the economic analysis. The port will offer, in the longer term,
the opportunity for the fishing fleet to keep operational through better O&M services

72.
Two  basic  economic  benefits  arise  due  to  rehabilitation  of  the  port.  The  first  is  the
recovery of the fleet to preconflict levels. This is expected to take five years. The value of the
fleet was assessed according to previous production costs: 11 m Japanese Bonito-class boats
cost $32,000 to produce and 14 m Lorosae-class boats cost $45,000. The preconflict value of
the  fleet  was  then  calculated  at  $698,000.  This  cost  will  not  be  met  from  the  Project,  but  is
expected to come from future private sector investment. From this calculated value, a deduction
was made of 40 percent as an assessed cost of repair. The residual value was then assumed to
be the economic value of the rehabilitated fleet.

In addition, due to the safer anchorage of the port, the reduced O&M costs for the fleet
